CutterNumber.Title: Cutter Number in the Library System
CutterNumber.Cutter number defi: A Cutter number (also known as Cutter Classification) is a part of the classification notation in many library systems. It was developed by Charles Ammi Cutter in the 19th century and is used to create a unique notation for each author or subject within a specific classification.
CutterNumber.Cutter number defi 2: The Cutter number is often used in conjunction with other classification systems such as DDC (Dewey Decimal Classification) or LCC (Library of Congress Classification) to create a unique call number for each library item.
CutterNumber.Cutter number intro: A typical Cutter number consists of:
CutterNumber.Cutter number detail 1: An initial letter (usually the first letter of the author's surname or subject)
CutterNumber.Cutter number detail 2: A number ranging from one to three digits
CutterNumber.Cutter number detail 3: Sometimes additional letters or numbers to distinguish between different works
CutterNumber.Cutter number sample: Example: S642 could be a Cutter number for an author with the surname Smith.
CutterNumber.Cutter number purpose intro: The Cutter number serves multiple purposes in the library system:
CutterNumber.Cutter number purpose detail 1: Creates a unique notation for each item
CutterNumber.Cutter number purpose detail 2: Arranges materials alphabetically by author or title within the same classification
CutterNumber.Cutter number purpose detail 3: Helps users and library staff easily locate and retrieve items from shelves
CutterNumber.Cutter number purpose detail 4: Allows for collection expansion without requiring changes to the entire classification system
CutterNumber.Cutter number sample detail: Below is an example of how a Cutter number is used in a call number:
CutterNumber.Cutter number sample code:
823.8 H356p
Where:
823.8 - DDC number for 19th-century English fiction
H356 - Cutter number for author Thomas Hardy
p - First letter of the title 'The Poor Man and the Lady'
CutterNumber.Cutter number sample code explain: In this example, H356 is the Cutter number. It is derived from the author's surname (Hardy) and a number to create a unique notation.
CutterNumber.Cutter number resource title intro: There are several useful tools and resources for learning about and generating Cutter numbers:
CutterNumber.Cutter number resource desc 1: A commonly used table for generating Cutter numbers.
CutterNumber.Cutter number resource desc 2: Provides information on how Cutter numbers are used in bibliographic records.
CutterNumber.Cutter number resource desc 3: An online tool for automatically generating Cutter numbers.
CutterNumber.Cutter number resource desc 4: The Cutter table used by the Library of Congress.
CutterNumber.Cutter number outro: Additionally, many university and public libraries provide guidelines on how to use and create Cutter numbers. You can check the website of your local library or nearby university for more information.

GuideMarc21.Title: Guide to Copy Cataloging with MARC21
GuideMarc21.copy catalog defi: Copy cataloging is the process of using an existing bibliographic record to create a new record for materials in your library. Instead of creating a completely new record from scratch, you can copy and edit an existing record to suit your specific material.
GuideMarc21.marc21 defi: MARC21 (Machine-Readable Cataloging) is a standard for encoding and exchanging bibliographic information. It provides a data structure for bibliographic records, allowing computers to read and process information about books, journals, and other materials.
GuideMarc21.progress catalog: Steps for Copy Cataloging with MARC21
GuideMarc21.progress catalog 1: Search for a suitable MARC21 record in databases or online catalogs. Some sources you can use:
GuideMarc21.progress catalog 2: Copy the MARC21 record into your library management system.
GuideMarc21.progress catalog 3: Review and edit the fields to accurately reflect the material in your collection.
GuideMarc21.progress catalog 4: Add local fields if necessary (e.g., call number, location, etc.).
GuideMarc21.progress catalog 5: Save the edited record into your library's catalog.
GuideMarc21.sample note: This is a simple example of a MARC21 record. Each line starts with a three-digit field followed by indicators and subfields marked by the dollar sign ($).

GuideDdc.Title: Dewey Decimal Classification (DDC) System
GuideDdc.DDC definition 1: The Dewey Decimal Classification (DDC) system is a widely used library classification system worldwide. Developed by Melvil Dewey in 1876, DDC provides a systematic way to organize and locate materials in libraries.
GuideDdc.DDC definition 2: DDC divides knowledge into 10 main classes, each of which is further divided into 10 subclasses, and so on. Each subject is assigned a number from 000 to 999, allowing for detailed classification and expansion as needed.
GuideDdc.DDC structure intro: DDC is organized into 10 main classes:
GuideDdc.DDC example code:
641.5 - Cooking
641.59 - Cooking by specific region
641.595 - Asian Cooking
641.5951 - Chinese Cooking
641.5952 - Japanese Cooking
GuideDdc.DDC example note: In this example, a book about Japanese cooking would be classified under the number 641.5952.
GuideDdc.DDC resources intro: There are several resources available to look up and learn more about DDC:
GuideDdc.DDC resource name 1: The official DDC website, which provides information and resources on the classification system.
GuideDdc.DDC resource name 2: Provides free access to the DDC summary table (first three digits).
GuideDdc.DDC resource name 3: Offers a community-based DDC lookup tool.
GuideDdc.DDC resource name 4: An experimental tool for finding DDC numbers based on titles or ISBNs.
GuideDdc.DDC additional info: Additionally, many public and university libraries also provide guides and materials on how to use DDC. You can check the website of your local library or nearest university for more information.
